awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Integrated Experimental and Computational Approach to Discover Biomechanical Mechanisms of Leaf Epidermal Morphogenesis
awd_abstract_narration:
The size and shape of leaves are important agricultural traits that strongly influence crop yield. The growth of individual cells collectively determine leaf morphology, and a major challenge in biology is to understand how cellular constituents pattern the cell wall to influence local rates and directions of cell growth. This project focuses on discovering the growth control mechanisms of the outer layer of cells that form the leaf epidermis. The epidermis serves both as a waterproof layer that protects the leaf and as a growing biomechanical shell that influences the size and shape of the leaf. This project aims to understand how cell signaling and cytoskeletal patterning is controlled among adherent cells and how local growth can scale to influence tissue or whole leaf traits.  The Broader Impact activities include interdisciplinary training for all members of the team (including undergraduates and high school students).  A K-12 summer camp module will also be developed for the Young Nebraska Scientist Program. 

The Arabidopsis leaf epidermal morphogenesis system is ideally suited for major breakthroughs. However, progress has been slow because of the lack of reliable phenotyping methods to define genetic pathways and analyze the non-intuitive biomechanical interactions that occur among the cytoskeleton, cell wall, and cell geometry. The interdisciplinary research team will create a new experimental and computational approach to discover how microtubule-dependent patterning of cellulose microfibrils drives polarized growth in the epidermis. The resulting computational models will make predictions about the how cells generate the spatial and temporal heterogeneities in the cell wall that drive interdigitated growth of these jig-saw-puzzle shaped cells. Importantly, biomechanical feedback control of the cell wall on the microtubule cytoskeleton is a general feature of plant development. The proposed research will generate data and create integrated computational models that reveal how cell wall stress patterns influence cortical microtubules and tissue morphogenesis.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

 

Leaves are important for photosynthesis. Their size, shape, and physical arrangement on the stem defines the efficiency with which plants can convert sunlight into sugars that drive plant growth and development. Leaf size and shape is determined by complex interactions among cell number, growth rate, and growth direction of groups of cells. There is a strong need to discover the cellular and biomechanical mechanisms that determine leaf morphology. The epidermal tissue has a special importance in this regard because its growth behaviors strongly influence the overall size and shape of the organ. In dicot leaves the epidermis is comprised of thick-walled jig-saw-puzzle piece shaped cells, termed pavement cells. Interdigitated growth of pavement drives morphogenesis, but the mechanism by which this polarized morphogenesis occurs is not known. The overall goal of this project was to determine how intracellular protein polymers termed microtubules can influence the material properties of the cell wall and generate an interdigitated growth pattern. We answered this question by developing novel time-lapsed imaging methods to cross correlate microtubule behaviors with cell shape change. We found that a subset of microtubules become locally aligned and stabilized, and this subset of microtubules provides a template that directs the cellulose fiber synthesizing machinery to generate a local patch of cell wall with highly aligned fibers. These aligned fibers drive polarized growth locally and this causes symmetry-breaking and the formation of new lobed cell morphology. Finite element computational models were used to demonstrate the plausibility of the proposed mechanism for interdigitated growth. It has long been hypothesized that microtubule localization and alignment respond to tensile forces in the cell wall. We used finite element models to quantitatively predict the magnitudes and directions of in-plane tensile forces in clusters of pavement cells with realistic geometries and material properties. Cross correlation microtubule analyses and experimental validations in pavement cell clusters with strongly altered tensile force patterns demonstrated a clear relationship between the magnitude and direction of forces and the orientation and stability of microtubules. These experiments predict a feedback loop between cell and tissue geometry, forces in the cell wall, and microtubule-dependent patterning of the wall. The growth outcome is a tissue morphology that underlies thin, large, and strong leaves. The mechanism by which extracellular forces are coupled to microtubules is not known; however, our team conducted a set of computational simulation experiments demonstrating how known force patterns in plant cell can robustly lead to microtubule patterns that are experimentally observed, if there is a hypothesized transmembrane receptor that links cell wall force sensing with a local alteration in microtubule behaviors.

 

Broader Impacts

 

The outcomes from this project provided a new and quantitative framework to analyze the complex relationships between invisible forces, complex cell and tissue geometries, and the mechanism by which plant cells generate a specialized cell wall that enables polarized growth. The work included 16 peer-reviewed publications. The researched revealed the cell-cell interface as a critical location for force-sensing and morphogenesis control. Future research aimed at engineering the important traits of leaf size and shape will draw from this new knowledge. Our results provide a generalizable model to explain how all plant cells can generate curved morphologies. In the underlying leaf mesophyll cells this growth behavior causes cells to detach from one another and generate air space that improves gas exchange and rates of photosynthesis. Our project partially overlapped with the Covid-19 pandemic, but the team adapted and created new opportunities for interdisciplinary training and learning for a broad base of scientists with vastly different levels of experience. Undergraduate students carried out experiments, analyzed data, and gained authorship on peer-reviewed publications. The project successfully trained the next generation of scientists that operate across disciplinary boundaries. Computational biologists, materials scientists, and plant biologists worked together to solve previously intractable problems in plant biology. The team created and published new finite element computational models, microtubule analysis software, and image processing pipelines like CelEct2.0 that have been made publicly available. Three students earned their PhDs with support from this project and are now pursuing careers in science and technology.
